From: J.D. Oder <jdo id="ypxccaphw5" data-rand="uhDZ96i3Kz"@shift4.com>
Sent: Thursday, August 27, 2020 3:52 PM
To: Jared Isaacman
Cc: Michael Isaacman; Taylor Lavery
Subject: Crypto

Jared,

Mike and I had a discussion with MoonPay. As a reminder, they facilitate the on/off-ramp for crypto (Coinbase
does the same - but I'm not in touch with them). Below are some high level notes from the conversation.

•   They operate in 160+ countries.
•   They support 30+ crypto currencies and 80+ assets.
•   They support a bunch of payment methods, including card brands.
•   Their fee include their margin and network fees.
•   They would structure a commercial model like:

Standard Fee

Our Fee

Volume

2.99% + Network Fees

TBD

$10M Year

2.49% + Network Fees

TBD

$25M Year

1.99% + Network Fees

TBD

$100M Year

The network fees direct hard cost. They use a model of multiple providers.

They would charge a blended rate to us (say $.25) and then we'd charge whatever we want
($.50).

We'd likely need to enhance the boarding and reporting APIs to make this happen.

They stressed that other gateways aren't making money on this - so their 1% proposed margin may be high.
They indicated some gateways take the loss to win volume in other areas. We need to find this out.

They are doing $2B a year volume.

We don't know enough about the market, but this seems like a good place to learn more.

What are your thoughts?

Thanks.

for again?

version of it

risk?

JDO: Correct - and it's something that we
can price and make margin on...

12/14/20,9:58 AM
JDO: All of our competitors only allow the
purchase of crypto - no gateway has the
ability to sell crypto back for USD - no
different than selling Euros for USD at the
airport

From: J.D. Oder <jdo id="0l4Nqw7xfI" data-rand="sFjqggLiDN"@shift4.com>
Sent: Thursday, August 27, 2020 3:52 PM
To: Jared Isaacman
Cc: Michael Isaacman; Taylor Lavery
Subject: Crypto

Jared,

Mike and I had a discussion with MoonPay. As a reminder, they facilitate the on/off-ramp for crypto (Coinbase
does the same - but I'm not in touch with them). Below are some high level notes from the conversation.

•   They operate in 160+ countries.
•   They support 30+ crypto currencies and 80+ assets.
•   They support a bunch of payment methods, including card brands.
•   Their fee include their margin and network fees.
•   They would structure a commercial model like:

Standard Fee

Our Fee

Volume

2.99% + Network Fees

TBD

$10M Year

2.49% + Network Fees

TBD

$25M Year

1.99% + Network Fees

TBD

$100M Year

The network fees direct hard cost. They use a model of multiple providers.

They would charge a blended rate to us (say $.25) and then we'd charge whatever we want
($.50).

We'd likely need to enhance the boarding and reporting APIs to make this happen.

They stressed that other gateways aren't making money on this - so their 1% proposed margin may be high.
They indicated some gateways take the loss to win volume in other areas. We need to find this out.

They are doing $2B a year volume.

We don't know enough about the market, but this seems like a good place to learn more.

What are your thoughts?

Thanks.

1 A. Yes.
2 Q. Tell me everything you remember about
3 discussions with Mr. Rumberg about the no
4 termination for convenience clause or an off-ramp.
5 A. Yeah. So, obviously, we wanted to be
6 fair, you know, with CardConnect and their
7 expectations, and we valued the relationship.
8 So an off-ramp that, you know, we both agreed
9 to -- that's what we were looking for. We
10 weren't looking for an out. We were looking for,
11 you know, a way to make a very complex, long-term
12 agreement work for both parties, and that included
13 an off-ramp.
14 Q. When you say, "We both agreed to," who
15 is "we"?
16 A. Well, that would be, you know, myself
17 and I believe Taylor Laresch on my team and
18 whoever was negotiating the agreement on their end.
19 I assumed it was Mr. Rumberg.

1 Q. Okay. And was it your expectation
2 going into the negotiation with CardConnect that
3 any agreement that you guys were able to reach
4 would include the right of Shift4 to terminate the
5 agreement for convenience?
6 A. I never -- I wouldn't say that was an
7 unwavering expectation. It was a preference.
8 I stated multiple times in the deposition
9 we wanted what was fair for both parties relative
10 to the risk of the agreement and the expectations
11 that were laid out by the CardConnect team.
12 Q. Okay. When you say it was a
13 "preference," was it a preference for you, or was
14 it a preference for Shift4?
15 A. I would say my personal preference
16 represented the preference of Shift4.
17 Q. Okay. Did you express that preference
18 to Mr. Rumberg?
19 A. Yes.

Subject: 	RE: First Data - Shift4 - Follow-up Items

Jeff,

As discussed, we can't commit to an agreement that doesn't provide an off-ramp for cause and convenience. We will certainly agree
to remedies/penalties, but if after 2-3 years have gone by and i think, we can only imagine how things can change, we need to protect
ourselves. I thought we left open the option to terminate for conv. w/ a penalty (i.e. pay a multiple of savings to buy-out deal and/or
waive retention bonus payments from them).
We just need an off-ramp.

Also, we can circle back on Monday to discuss in greater detail.

Thanks,
Jared
